questions.question: I ………………………. the minister tomorrow.
questions.description: The present continuous is used to refer to future events that are already arranged.

questions.question: ‘The phone is ringing.’ ‘I ………………………. it.’
questions.description: Will is used to announce our decisions.

questions.question: Good luck with the exam. I ………………………… of you.
questions.description: The future continuous is used to say that something will be in progress at a particular moment in the future.

questions.question: ……………………….. I turn the heating on?
questions.description: We use shall in polite offers and requests.

questions.question: All the trouble ………………………… by you.
questions.description: We use the passive verb here because the subject is not the doer of the action.

questions.question: When you phoned I ……………………….. in the garden.
questions.description: When we talk about two past events, we often use the past continuous for the longer background action.

questions.question: After I ………………………… with him for a few weeks, I developed a strange liking for him.
questions.description: The past perfect is used for the earlier of two past actions.

questions.question: When we were children we ……………………. go swimming every Sunday.
questions.description: Both would and used to can refer to repeated actions in the past.

questions.question: It would have been nice if he ………………………. us.
questions.description: In the third conditional we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: Sulphuric acid ……………………….. most metals.
questions.description: We use the simple future to talk about habits and characteristic behavior.

questions.question: I ………………………… the whole job by this evening.
questions.description: We use the future perfect tense to indicate that an action or situation will have been completed by a certain point of time in the past.
